Hey there!
  It's me again, and I'll try to make my two cents worth of nonsense somwhat 
comprehensible.
  That's certainly possible, although I've noticed in other cultures, women 
have also walked a step behind the men, for whatever reason.  The most 
notable one of recent memory is Raisa Gorbacheva, who, when appearing in 
public with Mikhail Gorbachev, ALWAYS walked a step back of him, and very 
rarely was seen even standing level with him.  I'm guessing it was (and may 
still be) a show of deference for whatever his position is -- even if the 
society (in whatever way) dictates (or the man himself dictates, whichever 
the case may be) that simply his being a MAN makes him worthy of walking the 
step ahead.  (Although I would hope that of the two, it is the first rather 
than the second.  The first is undesirable and avoided not without a great 
deal of difficulty.  The second, though, is insufferable and avoidable.)  
Although, I must say, tsukiyo's notion is at the VERY least, romantic and 
VERY laudable that a man would want to protect his lady like that.  Although, 
I would hope that he would only step the step ahead in the case that it were 
necessary, and the rest of the time he was with her, that they'd walk 
even-up.  That's about it.

Later.
T
